messageBody:
It depends what you have in your Spring XML. Often it is the
equivalent of "new" statements, defining the internal structure of the
code, rather than application configuration. If that is the case,
then you should test with the same Spring XML as you use in the real
application. Make sure the Spring XML contains no connection details
for your database. Configure those in a different way (properties
files for example). Have different connection parameters for your
test database and your production database.

In your persistence tests, clear the test database and call the
BankImpl (for example) to check that it can round-trip your persistent
objects. That will test that Spring, Hibernate and your code all
integrate together correctly.

Be careful with transactions and Hibernate's first-level cache so that
you're really are round-tripping objects into and out of the database
and not just using local copies from the EntityManager's cache.

--Nat
